Jiangsu Collaborative Innovation Center of Atmospheric Environment and Equipment Technology Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment Monitoring and Pollution Control Nanjing University of Information Science & Technology No.219, Ningliu Road Nanjing 210044 China The transition metal titanium-doped Mn-Ce-Ox catalysts catalyst were employed to achieve synergetic removal of NO and CB at 180–220 °C. The Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst with a molar ratio of Mn/Ce/Ti = 5:1:5 exhibits excellent activity, and the NOx and CB removal efficiencies reach 96 % and 89 % at 160–220 °C, respectively. The selectivity for N2 and CO2 are 93 % and 78 %, respectively. The N2-physisorption, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and XPS results show that Ti doping makes the catalyst possess a mesoporous structure, suitable particle sizes, and excellent redox and Lewis site properties. All of these features contribute to the observed high NO and CB removal efficiency. The synergetic removal of CB and NO over Mn5CeTi5Ox results from the synergistic catalysis between the redox and the solid acid. On the one hand, in the synergistic removal process, CB and NH3 are competitively adsorbed on the catalyst surface, resulting in a decrease in the NH3-SCR activity. On the other hand, the removal of NO and CB has a synergetic effect. The byproduct NO2 produced by the NH3-SCR reaction promotes the oxidation of CB, which is beneficial for CB removal. Moreover, the consumption of NO2 indirectly promotes the NH3-SCR reaction, which partially compensates for the decrease in the NO removal efficiency caused by competitive adsorption between NH3 and CB. Ti doping promotes the participation of the SCR byproduct NO2 in the CBCO reaction and promotes the formation of maleic acid, an intermediate product of CB oxidation. In summary, the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst exhibits good activity for the synergistic removal of NOx and CB and is a promising candidate for the effective and economical removal of NO and CB during waste incineration. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Synergistic catalytic removal NOx CB Intermediate products Removal mechanism Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction For waste incineration, metal smelting and other industries, a series of polluting gases, including both NOx and chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs), are produced in the subsequent emission process; Chlorobenzene (CB) is a common chlorinated volatile organic compound [1–3]. These compounds are precursors of photochemical smog [4]. These polluting gases enter the atmosphere and negatively impact human survival and life. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology is mainly used for the removal of NOx. Catalytic oxidation technology is used for the removal of CB [5]. The low content of volatile chlorinated organic compounds in polluted gas hinders the use of separate devices for treatment. Therefore, realizing the synergistic removal of NOx and CB is highly important [6]. In the NH3-SCR reaction, the Mn-based catalyst still follows the Eley-Rideal (E-R) and Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) reaction mechanisms. In the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism, gaseous NO first reacts with the activated NH3 adsorbed species to form intermediate products and then decomposes into N2 and H2O [7,8]. The main reaction equation for the SCR reaction is given by Eq. (1). In the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism, gaseous NO is adsorbed on the basic site and further reacts with adjacent activated NH3 to form N2 and H2O [9]. CB catalytic oxidation (CBCO) involves the adsorption of aromatics on the surface of a catalyst. Cl- is attacked by nucleophiles and replaced by O2-, and the remaining aromatic rings are further oxidized by electrophilic substitution [10].The main reaction equation of CBCO is given by Eq. (2). Both NH3-SCR and CBCO utilize the surface acidity and redox properties of the catalyst to achieve synergistic removal of two substances under one catalyst. Because the temperature ranges of NOx and CB removal differ, balancing the surface acidity and redox properties of the catalyst within a certain temperature range is very important [9]. (1) 4NH3 + 4NO +O2 → 4N2 + 6H2O (2) C6H5Cl + 7O2 → 6CO2 + HCl+2H2O Vanadium-based catalysts are widely used in the synergistic control of NOx and chlorinated organics. Zhai et al. [11] investigated the effect of the reaction characteristics of monomeric and polymeric vanadium on the catalytic synergistic elimination of NOx and CB. The main adsorption site of CB on the monomer domain is the V-OH bond, and the main adsorption site on the polymer domain is the V=O bond. The monomeric vanadium group is conducive to the conversion of Lewis V=O to Brønsted V=OH, which provides sufficient H protons for the formation of HCl, and the polymer species can effectively retain the V4+ and V5+ redox cycles and generate activity in the CB oxidation reaction. However, the abundant oxygen vacancies and Cl- lead to the formation of many polychlorinated byproducts on the polyoxovanadium catalyst via the formation of V-Cl bonds. M. G et al. [12] investigated the catalytic activity of vanadium oxides supported on TiO2 for the simultaneous removal of the typical pollutants NO and 1,2-dichlorobenzene (o-DCB) in the flue gas of a municipal solid waste incinerator (MWI). Catalysts with different vanadium loadings were prepared to obtain catalysts with different VOx species groups ranging from isolated crystals to aggregated and segregated crystals. Moreover, NO was not completely removed on the carrier with a higher vanadium oxide loading, and simultaneous and efficient removal of NOx and 1,2-dichlorobenzene (o-DCB) could not be achieved. To solve the above problems [13], manganese-based catalysts have been analyzed. MnOx catalysts have received extensive attention because of their excellent catalytic activity at low temperatures due to their diverse valence states, abundant active centers, and strong redox ability [14]. However, the wide application of single metal oxide catalysts in industrial environments is hindered by their limited mechanical strength and relatively small specific surface area [15]. To solve the defects of single-component metal catalysts, Mn-Ce bimetallic catalysts have been analyzed. Mn-Ce catalysts have good performance for the synergistic removal of NO and CB. Gan et al [16]. investigated the catalytic performance of MnOx–CeO2 for the simultaneous reduction of NO and CB. Owing to the formation of a MnOx(0.4)–CeO2 solid solution and the good balance between the redox properties and surface acidity, MnOx(0.4)–CeO2 exhibits excellent catalytic activity. However, the SCR reaction and CB oxidation have different temperature reaction ranges, and efficient synergistic removal of NO and CB cannot be achieved. Previously, in the early study, our research team has developed the Mn-Ce-Ox (Mn/Ce=5:1 in mol) catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO at the low-temperature and it showed good catalytic performance for NH3-SCR of NO and anti-poison ability at 100–250 °C [17]. In response to these problems, in this work, the transition metal titanium-doped Mn-Ce-Ox catalysts catalyst were employed to achieve synergetic removal of NO and CB at 180–220 °C. The synergetic removal performance of NO and CB over Mn5CeTi5Ox and its mechanism were systematically investigated. Moreover, the promotion mechanism of Ti doping on catalyst performance was also analyzed by XRD, BET, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, XPS and in situ DRIFTS. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Mn-Ce-Ox catalyst was prepared via a coprecipitation method. First, 100 ml of pure water was weighed with a measuring cylinder and heated to a constant temperature of 30 °C on a magnetic stirrer. Second, a certain amount of oxalic acid was weighed and placed in constant-temperature pure water, and the saturated oxalic acid solution obtained by filtering out the precipitate was recorded as solution A. Solution B was prepared according to a Mn:Ce molar ratio of 5:1 and then uniformly added to solution A with a pipette gun under uniform stirring. After stirring for 2 h and standing for 12 h, solution B was centrifuged and alternately washed with ultrapure water and alcohol 5–6 times. The Mn-Ce-Ox catalyst was obtained by calcining the centrifuged sample in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 2 h after drying at 80 °C in a constant-temperature drying oven. To prepare transition metal titanium-doped Mn-Ce-Ox catalysts, in this experiment, TiO2 was doped into Mn-Ce-Ox catalysts. The preparation method was the same as that used for coprecipitation. Mn-Ce-Ti-Ox catalysts were prepared via the sol–gel method. First, a certain amount (determined by the molar ratio) of but yl titanate and 25 ml of anhydrous ethanol were weighed with a measuring cylinder, poured into the same beaker and stirred on a magnetic stirrer for 20 min to obtain solution A. Second, 12 ml of glacial acetic acid, 5 ml of pure water and a certain amount of anhydrous ethanol were mixed with Mn nitrate and Ce nitrate at a molar ratio of 5:1. Solution B was obtained by stirring this mixture for 10 min with a magnetic stirrer. Solution B was poured into solution A and stirred to obtain the Mn-Ce-Ti-Ox composite sol. Last, the sol was covered with plastic wrap for aging for 24 h, dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 500 °C in a muffle furnace. The samples were removed for grinding and sieving to obtain the Mn-Ce-Ti-Ox catalyst. The molar ratios of Mn/Ce/Ti were 5:1:1; 5:1:2; 5:1:3; 5:1:4; and 5:1:5. 2.2 Catalyst activity measurements Catalyst activity tests were carried out in a continuous flow fixed bed with a mass flow meter to control the intake gas (the carrier gas was N2, the feed gas was chlorobenzene and N2, and the rest was NH3, NO and O2). A quartz tube with a diameter of 0.8 cm was used, and a wire mesh and quartz cotton were first loaded on the lower side of the quartz tube to fix the catalyst to prevent its leakage. Then, 1 ml of the catalyst powder along with an 80 mesh sieve was taken and loaded into the tube. The quartz tube was fixed in a temperature programmed furnace with a fixing device, and the catalytic test was carried out by regulating the temperature programmed furnace. The conditions of the synergistic test were as follows: the total space velocity was 24,000 h-1, the concentrations of NO and NH3 were 600 ppm, the concentration of chlorobenzene was 50 ppm, the concentration of oxygen was 6 vol. %, and the rest was N2. The CB in the inlet and outlet gas was detected via an online gas chromatograph (GC-9790), and the NOx concentration was detected via a German Eco flue gas analyzer. Because the proportion of NO in exhaust NOx is greater than 95 %, laboratory researchers regard the removal rate of NO as the removal rate of NOx. The NOx conversion and CB conversion were evaluated according to the formula given below. (3) NO x conversion ( % ) = ( [ NO x ] in − [ NO x ] out ) / [ NO x ] in × 100 % (4) CB conversion ( % ) = ( X 0 − X ) / X 0 × 100 % The “in” and “out” subscripts indicate the inlet and outlet concentrations, respectively, of NO in the steady state. X0 is the base peak area, and X is the postreaction test peak area. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. The morphology and composition of the surface ultrastructures of various solid substances were observed with JEOL and JSM-5900 instruments. The surface morphology of the catalysts was observed by scanning images. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method was performed via an ASAP 2020M V3.00H specific surface area and micropore analyzer from Micromeritics Company in the United States to determine the specific surface area, pore volume and pore size of the prepared catalysts. A Rigaku D max/RB X-ray diffractometer was used to analyze the crystal structure of the catalysts. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed using a semiautomatic Micromeritics TPD/TPR 2900 instrument. Ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were carried out using a semiautomatic Micromeritics TPD/TPR 2900 instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using an AXISULTRA DLD with Al-Kα radiation as the monochromatic light source. A Nicolet Nexus 670 Fourier transform spectrometer (in situ DRIFTS) from Thermo Electron Company in the United States was used for testing. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst activities 3.1.1 Synergistic removal of NOx and CB by the Ti-doped Mn-Ce-Ox catalysts The NOx removal rates of the Mn-Ce-Ti-Ox catalysts doped with different contents of Ti are shown in Fig. 1 (a). The NOx removal rates of pure TiO2 and the Mn-Ce-Ox catalysts doped with different contents of Ti at 130–250 °C are shown, and the NOx removal rate of pure TiO2 is the lowest, at only 50 %. In comparison, the NOx removal rates of the Me-Ce-Ox catalysts doped with Ti are much greater than that of pure TiO2, and Ti doping is beneficial for improving the NOx removal rate. In the temperature range of 130–160 °C, the efficiency of the catalytic removal of NOx by the seven catalysts gradually increases. The denitrification efficiency of Mn5CeTiOx, Mn5CeTi4Ox and Mn5CeTi5Ox exceed 95 % at 160 °C. As the temperature increases, the removal rate gradually decreases, mainly because of the adsorption saturation of the catalysts and the decrease in the desorption capacity. Mn5CeTi5Ox does not exhibit a significant decrease and has good activity. The catalytic oxidation of CB on the Mn-Ce-Ti-Ox catalysts with different contents of doped Ti is shown in Fig. 1 (b). Pure TiO2 and the Mn5-Ce-Ox catalysts have poor catalytic oxidation effects on CB over the entire temperature range. With increasing Ti doping amount, the removal rate of CB is significantly improved, indicating that the addition of titanium can improve the oxidation activity of the catalyst for CB. In the range of 130–250 °C, the catalytic efficiencies of the seven catalysts tend to increase, and only the catalytic efficiency of Mn5CeTi5Ox slightly decreases at 190 °C, which may be due to the desorption of some adsorbed CB after the temperature increases. Overall, the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst shows the best CB removal activity, consistent with the denitration results. The synergistic removal rates of NOx and CB by the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalysts at 130–250 °C are shown in Fig. 2 (a). The removal rate of NOx is slightly improved, and the removal rate of CB is improved as a whole, indicating that NOx and CB simultaneously exist and that there is a synergistic effect. The NOx and CB removal efficiencies reach 96% and 89%, respectively, at 160-220 °C. The N2 selectivity of the Mn-Ce-Ti-Ox catalysts doped with different contents of Ti is shown in Fig. 1 (c). In the range of 130–160 °C, the N2 selectivity of all the catalysts is 100 %. With increasing temperature, the selectivity for N2 gradually decreases. Compared with that of the other catalysts, the selectivity of the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst at 250 °C reaches 86 %, which is consistent with the activity of the catalyst. The CO2 selectivity of the Mn-Ce-Ti-Ox catalysts doped with different contents of Ti is shown in Fig. 1 (d). In the range of 130–250 °C, the CO2 selectivity gradually increases with increasing temperature, indicating that the higher the temperature is the stronger the CB oxidation, and the CO2 selectivity of the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalysts reaches 76% at 250 °C, which is consistent with the activity for denitrification and CB removal reported in the previous study [18]. The N2 selectivity and CO2 selectivity of Mn5CeTi5Ox are shown in Fig. 2 (b). During the process of synergistic removal, the selectivity of N2 slightly decreases with increasing temperature, whereas the CO2 selectivity slightly increases with increasing temperature, the selectivity for N2 and CO2 are 93 % and 78 %, respectively. Therefore, it can be speculated that this is due to the formation of intermediate products such as NO2 by the SCR side reaction [19]. NO2 has strong oxidizability, which can promote CB oxidation and promote the NH3-SCR reaction. To further prove the effect of NO2 on CBCO, the effect of each single SCR reaction gas on the CB conversion rate of the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst was investigated. The effect of each single SCR reaction gas on the CB conversion rate is shown in Fig. 3 (a). After the introduction of NO2, the CB conversion rate increases throughout the temperature range, indicating that the strong oxidation of NO2 promotes the CBCO reaction. There is no significant change in the CB conversion rate when NO gas is introduced alone, whereas NH3 competes with CB on the catalyst surface, resulting in a decrease in the CB conversion. Fig. 3 (b) shows the effect of each SCR reaction gas on the CO2 selectivity of the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst, which is consistent with the results shown in Fig. 3 (a). 3.2 Analysis of the physicochemical and structural properties of the catalyst 3.2.1 Specific surface area and pore structure analysis The catalysts were characterized via the BET method to determine their specific surface area, pore volume and average pore size. The results are shown in Table 1 . The surface structures of the five catalysts doped with different titanium materials are different. Mn5CeTi5Ox has the largest specific surface area, with a specific surface area of 114.84 m2·g-1; the pore volume and pore size are also relatively large, and the catalyst has the highest activity for NOx and CB removal. In contrast, the Mn5CeTi2Ox catalyst has the smallest specific surface area, pore volume and pore size and the worst activity for the catalytic removal of NOx and CB. A comparison of Mn5CeTi5Ox with Mn5CeTi2Ox reveals that the pore volume, pore size and specific surface area of the catalyst are related to the activity of the catalyst and that different surface structures affect the activity of the catalyst. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the different Ti-doped Mn5-Ce-Ox catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . Fig. 4 (a) shows that the three curves belong to type II (S-type) isotherms. Because of the aggregation of capillary phenomena, the desorption amount of N2 is less than the adsorption amount under the adsorption and aggregation of capillary pores. Therefore, at a relative pressure P/P0 > 0.5, all the catalysts have H3-type hysteresis loops, indicating that many mesoporous junctions exist between the catalyst particles. When P/P0 > 0.4, the rising slope of the catalyst adsorption isotherm gradually increases, mainly because the capillary adsorption phenomenon occurs on the surface of the catalyst, and the amount of adsorbed gas rapidly increases. In addition, the pore size distribution of the catalyst shows that the pore size distribution of all the catalysts is in the range of 2-10 nm, as shown in Fig. 4 (b). A rich mesoporous structure helps improve the specific surface area of the catalyst [20]. This also improves the activity of the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst. 3.2.2 XRD phase analysis The XRD patterns of the Mn-Ce-Ti-Ox catalysts with different amounts of added Ti are shown in Fig. 5 . The XRD analysis results indicate that there is an obvious characteristic diffraction peak of anatase TiO2 at 25.2°. With the continuous change in the Ti content, the intensity of the diffraction peak gradually increases. When the molar ratio of Mn/Ce/Ti is 5:1:5, the removal rates of NOx and CB are the highest, indicating that the addition of Ti oxide can promote the activity of the catalyst. Moreover, the diffraction peaks of MnO2 are located at 2θ values of 37.6° and 43.2°, and the diffraction peak of CeO2 can be observed at 63.4°. The XRD pattern analysis reveals that the diffraction peaks of CeO2 and MnO2 are wide and that the intensity is weak, indicating that the crystal of the transition metal oxide in the catalytically active component coexists with the weak crystalline state, forming a multiphase coexistence transition metal oxide, which is beneficial to the SCR denitrification and CB removal reaction. 3.2.3 H2-TPR The Mn5CeOx catalysts, TiOx catalysts and Mn5CeTiOx, Mn5CeTi3Ox, and Mn5CeTi5Ox catalysts prepared via the sol-gel method were characterized via H2-TPR, and the redox properties of the catalysts were investigated. Fig. 6 shows that the TiOx catalyst has an obvious reduction peak at 554 °C, and no other obvious reduction peaks are observed at lower temperatures. This may be due to a large change in its crystal structure or a reduction peak corresponding to a higher temperature. There are three reduction peaks for the Mn-Ce-Ox catalyst, corresponding to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3, from Mn2O3 to Mn3O4, and from Mn3O4 to MnO. The reduction peaks at 236 °C and 361 °C belong to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 and Mn2O3 to Mn3O4, respectively, while the high temperature peak at 478 °C belongs to the reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO [21,22]. However, the Mn5CeTiOx and Mn5CeTi5Ox catalysts have only one obvious reduction peak, which may be caused by the change in the crystal structure caused by the doping of Ti. Compared with that of pure Mn-Ce, the reduction peak of the Ti-doped catalyst is not obvious, which may be caused by the strong interaction between the Ti species and the Mn species. The relative area of the reduction peak of the Mn-Ce-Ti-Ox catalyst is relatively large. The reduction peak of Mn5CeTi5Ox is consistent with that of the Mn-Ce catalyst, and the reduction peak area is the largest, indicating that this catalyst has excellent redox performance. This may also explain the increase in denitrification and CB removal activity after the addition of Ti-doped Mn-Ce-Ox. 3.2.4 NH3-TPD The NH3-TPD diagrams of the Mn5CeOx, TiOx and Mn5CeTi5Ox catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . The surface acidity of the catalysts was analyzed via NH3-TPD. Fig. 7 clearly shows that between 100 and 300 °C, the three catalysts have an obvious ammonia desorption peak. In general, this position corresponds to the desorption of ammonia adsorbed by the catalyst on the weaker acid site. The diagram also shows that the three catalysts also have a desorption peak of ammonia gas near 600 °C, which may correspond to the desorption of ammonia gas adsorbed by the catalysts at the strong acid site. In addition, comparing the pure manganese cerium catalyst and the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst, the former has a desorption peak at 134 °C, and the latter has a desorption peak at 236 °C. The desorption peak of the latter is 100 °C higher than that of the former, which also explains why the denitration temperature of the catalyst increases to 250 °C after titanium doping. The relative area of the desorption peak of the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst is also larger than that of the Mn5CeOx catalyst, and the peak is wider. This is one of the reasons for the increase in denitrification and CB removal activity. After Ti doping, no new NH3 reduction peak appears for Mn5CeTi5Ox, indicating that Ti doping does not introduce new acid sites. 3.2.5 Surface element analysis The elemental compositions of the Mn5CeOx catalysts, TiOx catalysts and Mn5CeTi5Ox catalysts prepared via the sol-gel method were analyzed. The XPS spectra of the different catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . XPS can be used to analyze the composition of the surface elements of a catalyst, determine the valence state and content of the surface elements of the catalyst, and explore the interactions among the elements. Table 2 shows the surface atomic concentrations of the different catalysts. The Ti 2p XPS spectra, which is Ti4+ peaks, for the different catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 (a). The two characteristic peaks of Ti for the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst at 458.45 eV and 464.2 eV correspond to Ti4+, Compared with that of the TiOx catalyst, the binding energy of the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst shifts in the direction of a low binding energy, indicating that electron transfer occurred in the catalyst. The O 1s XPS spectra of the different catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 (b). After the O 1s peak is fitted, it can be divided into surface lattice oxygen (Oβ) and surface adsorbed oxygen (Oα) [23,24]. With the addition of titanium to the Mn5CeOx catalyst, the O 1s peak shifts, which proves that an interaction occurred between Ti and O. Notably, the surface adsorbed oxygen is more active than the surface lattice oxygen. According to the surface atomic concentration data in Table 2, the Oα/(Oα+Oβ) concentration of the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst is the highest, indicating that the addition of titanium improves the activity of oxygen, which is consistent with the catalytic removal of NOx and CB. The Mn 2p XPS spectra of the different catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 (c). The peak at a binding energy of 652.8 eV corresponds to Mn 2p1/2, and the peak at a binding energy of 641.5 eV corresponds to Mn 2p3/2. It has been well established that the Mn 2p3/2 peak could be deconvoluted into three peaks: Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+. The high-valence manganese atoms in the manganese-containing catalyst have high activity, indicating that the activity of Mn4+ is greater than that of Mn3+. Therefore, medium and high proportions of Mn4+/Mnn+ in the catalyst can promote the SCR and catalytic CB reactions. The Ce 3d XPS spectra of the different catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 (d). The binding energy peaks marked as u1, u2, u3, u4 and u5 (3d3/2) and v1, v2, v3 and v4 (3d5/2) corresponded to Ce4+ in CeO2, while u4 and v3 were assigned to Ce3+ in Ce2O3 [17,25]. This may be due to the addition of titanium promoting a shift of the binding energy to a higher position, which will cause the radius of the catalyst particles to increase, consistent with the BET test results above. 3.3 Study on the collaborative removal mechanism Fig. 9 shown the in situ DRIFTS reaction between NH3, NO and O2 over Mn5CeTi5Ox at 190 °C. Fig. 9 (a) shows that there is no significant change in the spectrum before the introduction of NH3 for 3 min. After 5 min, N-H stretching vibration peaks at 3382 and 3247 cm-1, which correspond to adsorbed NH3, can be clearly observed. The consumption peak of the hydroxyl group (the inverted peaks at 3611 and 1636 cm-1) increases with time, indicating that the adsorption of NH3 on the Brønsted acid site is further strengthened. The peak at 1458 cm-1 corresponds to the vibration of NH3 adsorbed on the Brønsted acid site, which increases with time [10,26]. The adsorption peaks at 1600 and 1178 cm-1 corresponding to the Lewis acid sites increase with adsorption time, indicating that the prepared catalyst could effectively adsorb NH3. Fig. 9 (b) shows a peak at 1004 cm-1 corresponding to the intermediate product N2O2 2-, which is related to the coordinated adsorption of NO on the catalyst surface. The peak at 1610 cm-1 corresponds to bridging nitrate, and those at 1559 and 1238 cm-1 correspond to bidentate nitrate and monodentate nitrate, respectively. The increase in the peak area during adsorption shows that NO and O2 react with pre-adsorbed NH3 following the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. To further investigate the effects of the Ti additive on NOx removal and CB oxidation, Fig. 10 (a) presents the in situ DRIFTS reaction results of NH3, NO and O2 over Mn5CeOx at 190 °C. After 3 min, the spectrum significantly changes, and the N-H stretching vibration peak of adsorbed NH3 appears at 3361 cm-1. After 3 min, the spectra significantly changes, and the N-H stretching vibration peak of adsorbed NH3 appears at 3361 cm-1 [27,28]. The N-H symmetric vibration peak of NH3 on Lewis acid sites appears at 1196 cm-1, and the vibration peaks of bidentate nitrate and monodentate nitrate appear at 1557 cm-1 and 1242 cm-1, respectively. The asymmetric bending vibration peak of NH4+ appears at 1464 cm-1, and the asymmetric peak of NH4 + at the Brønsted site appears at 1359 cm-1 [29]. With increasing adsorption time, the vibration peak of the intermediate bridging nitric acid and bidentate nitrate products gradually increases, and the vibration peak of NH4+ at 1464 cm-1 also gradually increases. The absorption peak of NH3 on the Lewis acid site can be clearly observed after the SCR gas is introduced for 5 min [14]. This peak shows that the SCR reaction is ongoing. Fig. 10 (d) presents the in situ DRIFTS reaction results of NH3, NO and O2 over Mn5CeTi5Ox at 190 °C. With the doping of Ti, the area of the Lewis acid peaks increases, indicating promoted adsorption of NH3. These findings indicate that titanium doping promotes the SCR reaction, which is well consistent with the denitration activity of Mn5CeTi5Ox. Fig. 10 (b) presents the in situ DRIFTS reaction results of NH3, NO and O2 adsorption on Mn5CeOx with pre-adsorbed CB at 190 °C. The vibration peaks of the intermediate bridging nitrate (1176 cm-1) and monodentate nitrate (1242 cm-1) weaken, and the introduced chlorobenzene occupies some of the active sites on the catalyst and reduces the rate of the SCR reaction. Owing to the simultaneous occurrence of the SCR reaction and chlorobenzene oxidation, the characteristic peaks of SCR and chlorobenzene oxidation are not obvious. The vibration peak of the intermediate product NO2 in the SCR reaction appears at 1627 cm-1. The vibration peak of maleic acid salt, the intermediate product of CB oxidation, appears at 1490 cm-1, indicating that CB reacts on the surface of the catalyst, but the reaction on the surface of the catalyst is mainly an SCR reaction. Fig. 10 (e) presents the in situ DRIFTS reaction results of NH3, NO and O2 adsorption on Mn5CeTi5Ox with pre-adsorbed CB. The vibration peaks of maleic acid salt and bridging nitrate are enhanced, and doping of Ti is beneficial for the formation of intermediate products while promoting the SCR reaction and CB oxidation. The vibration peak of NO2 disappears, indicating that titanium doping promotes the generation of NO2 to participate in the CBCO reaction, which is beneficial for the CBCO reaction and is consistent with the increase in CO2 selectivity in the above synergistic reaction. Fig. 10 (c) presents the in situ DRIFTS reaction results of NH3, NO and O2 adsorption on Mn5CeOx with pre-adsorbed CB at 190 °C. The hydroxyl consumption peak generated by the combination of CB and Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst surface appears at 3643 cm-1, and the CO2 splitting vibration peak appears at 2340 cm-1. With increasing adsorption time, the vibration peaks of maleate species are enhanced (1181, 1493 cm-1) [30]. The CB molecules remaining on the catalyst are further oxidized. Because the intermediate product NO2 of the SCR reaction has a strong oxidizing property, it is beneficial for the oxidation of CB. To a certain extent, the presence of CB slightly inhibit the SCR reaction [31]. On the other hand, the intermediate product NO2 of the SCR reaction promotes the oxidation of CB. Fig. 10 (f) shows the in situ DRIFTS reaction results of NH3, NO and O2 adsorption on Mn5CeTi5Ox with pre-adsorbed CB. The characteristic infrared peak of CB is replaced by the characteristic peak of NH4+, and the intermediate product of CB oxidation and the intermediate product of the SCR reaction react to form the byproduct polychlorobenzene [32]. With doping of Ti, the vibration peak of maleate at 1198 cm-1 is enhanced. To a certain extent, the oxidation reaction of CB is promoted. The mechanism of the synergistic removal of NOx and CB by Mn5CeTi5Ox is shown in Fig. 11 . Competitive adsorption of adsorbed CB and NH3 occurs at Brønsted acid sites [33]. NH2 is oxidized to NH/N by adsorbed O2 and then reduced to N2 by NO. The unreduced NH/H reacts with O2 to form NO, and the generated NO continues to react with O2 to form the intermediate products NO2 and N2O. With increasing Ti doping amount, the N2 selectivity gradually increases, and the amount of intermediate products also increases. The intermediate product of the NH3-SCR reaction has a strong oxidizing property to promote partial CB oxidation such that the SCR reaction moves in the direction of N2 generation, which is consistent with the results shown in Fig. 2. CB is oxidized by O2 to intermediate products such as maleic anhydride (DCMA) and chlorobenzene p-benzoquinone. With increasing Ti doping amount, the intermediate products are further oxidized to HCl, CO2, CO and polychlorinated benzenes [10,34–36]. With doping of Ti, the intermediate products of the SCR and CB oxidation reactions increase, indicating that Ti doping promotes the synergistic removal of NO and CB to a certain extent. 4 Conclusion In this work, the transition metal titanium-doped Mn-Ce-Ox catalysts catalyst were employed to achieve synergetic removal of NO and CB at 180–220 °C. The Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst with a molar ratio of Mn/Ce/Ti = 5:1:5 exhibits excellent activity, and the NOx and CB removal efficiencies reach 96 % and 89 % at 160–220 °C, respectively. The selectivity for N2 and CO2 are 93 % and 78 %, respectively. The N2-physisorption, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and XPS results show that Ti doping makes the catalyst possess a mesoporous structure, suitable particle sizes, and excellent redox and Lewis site properties. All of these features contribute to the observed high NO and CB removal efficiency. The synergetic removal of CB and NO over Mn5CeTi5Ox results from the synergistic catalysis between the redox and the solid acid. On the one hand, in the synergistic removal process, CB and NH3 are competitively adsorbed on the catalyst surface, resulting in a decrease in the NH3-SCR activity. On the other hand, the removal of NO and CB has a synergetic effect. The byproduct NO2 produced by the NH3-SCR reaction promotes the oxidation of CB, which is beneficial for CB removal. Moreover, the consumption of NO2 indirectly promotes the NH3-SCR reaction, which partially compensates for the decrease in the NO removal efficiency caused by competitive adsorption between NH3 and CB. Ti doping promotes the participation of the SCR byproduct NO2 in the CBCO reaction and promotes the formation of maleic acid, an intermediate product of CB oxidation. The Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst exhibits good activity for the synergistic removal of NOx and CB and is a promising candidate for the effective and economical removal of NO and CB during waste incineration. coredata.dc:description: The transition metal titanium-doped Mn-Ce-Ox catalysts catalyst were employed to achieve synergetic removal of NO and CB at 180–220 °C. The Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst with a molar ratio of Mn/Ce/Ti = 5:1:5 exhibits excellent activity, and the NOx and CB removal efficiencies reach 96 % and 89 % at 160–220 °C, respectively. The selectivity for N2 and CO2 are 93 % and 78 %, respectively. The N2-physisorption, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and XPS results show that Ti doping makes the catalyst possess a mesoporous structure, suitable particle sizes, and excellent redox and Lewis site properties. All of these features contribute to the observed high NO and CB removal efficiency. The synergetic removal of CB and NO over Mn5CeTi5Ox results from the synergistic catalysis between the redox and the solid acid. On the one hand, in the synergistic removal process, CB and NH3 are competitively adsorbed on the catalyst surface, resulting in a decrease in the NH3-SCR activity. On the other hand, the removal of NO and CB has a synergetic effect. The byproduct NO2 produced by the NH3-SCR reaction promotes the oxidation of CB, which is beneficial for CB removal. Moreover, the consumption of NO2 indirectly promotes the NH3-SCR reaction, which partially compensates for the decrease in the NO removal efficiency caused by competitive adsorption between NH3 and CB. Ti doping promotes the participation of the SCR byproduct NO2 in the CBCO reaction and promotes the formation of maleic acid, an intermediate product of CB oxidation. In summary, the Mn5CeTi5Ox catalyst exhibits good activity for the synergistic removal of NOx and CB and is a promising candidate for the effective and economical removal of NO and CB during waste incineration.
